When I said that the Frankfurt School added a new layer of analysis to the understanding of society, I meant that they expanded on the ideas developed by Karl Marx and other early Marxist thinkers. Marx and early Marxism focused primarily on the economic and class structures of society, and the ways in which these structures produced and maintained inequality and oppression. The Frankfurt School, on the other hand, added an interdisciplinary approach that included psychology, sociology, philosophy, and other fields in their analysis. They also added a greater emphasis on the role of culture and ideology in shaping society, and the ways in which individuals internalize and resist these ideologies.

Regarding new forms of knowledge, Foucault argued that power and knowledge are closely linked and that power is not just repressive, it is also productive. It creates new forms of knowledge, ways of understanding the world, shapes our desires and beliefs. He also argued that knowledge and power are deeply intertwined and that knowledge is not neutral but is produced and used in the service of power.

Regarding the Frankfurt School's emphasis on the individual's critical power to change society, Marx had indeed called for revolution from the lower class, and the Frankfurt School also emphasized the need for a revolution, but they also emphasized the need for individuals to critically examine and change themselves and the ways they internalize and support oppressive societal structures. They also placed a greater emphasis on the role of culture and ideology in shaping society, and the ways in which individuals internalize and resist these ideologies.
